ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Todd is a great instructor! He explains concepts clearly and is always available for your questions and even extra time outside of class. I've enjoyed this course very much!

I really enjoyed the course overall. I think the group work meant students did not engage with the material as much as they could have though. Most groups had an obvious freeloader, and the work was pretty easily spread out, so I felt disincentivized to do as much external research as I would have otherwise. The straight lectures were surprisingly useful and engaging. Overall, I'd like a more prodding though. There was little to no reason to read for the class, as the discussions did not seem to build on them all that much. Despite these qualms, it was one of my favorite courses.
Todd Cout is amazing. This class was very conceptually stimulating and applicable to other coursework. It's a very practical class.

8-12: I loved this course!! I thought Todd is an excellent and engaging instructor, who is not content with seeing things as black or white but rather engaging and accepting the complex realities of the world. In this case, corporate sustainability, that means accepting that it is murky and there are no clear good answers. I enjoyed that he was very relaxed and engaging, very accommodating and responsive to students. I also enjoyed the group projects and the individual project. I think this is an excellent course for anyone interested in corporate sustaianbility. I am frankly shocked about the poor reviews that previous students gave this course--a reason why I almost did not take it. I am so glad I did, it might have been my favorite course this semester--it made me want to engage with corporate sustainability, even as someone initially rather skeptical about working with the private sector.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: the lectures and group assignments
The cases

I wanted courses that were practical and this course definitely fits the bill. I like how the frameworks and tools are so relevant and up-to-date. For me especially coming from a developing country, this course exposed me to a whole new suite of standards which I highly appreciated.
First half of the class was good - going over good metrics, standards, etc. Todd is great one on one. I liked the personal solution assignment.
Todd has an incredible wealth of knowledge, and gives practical, useful feedback. In what can be considered by some to be a dry subject, he finds a way to make it interesting!
The in-class assignments that we worked on in groups.
Tangible practical assignments that force one to practice what we are learning in class. I also liked the green light sessions. I'd never expereinced one before.

Todd's teaching, his presentations of how things are not black or white. I also really enjoyed the group projects and the individual project. I especially liked the conceptual focus on metrics and indicators throughout the semester.

I was hesitant to take the class given previous years' comments, but Todd has improved the class a great deal. Todd is excellent in explaining the concepts using diagrams and real world examples. He has a lot of experience in the corporate sustainability & sustainable finance world, and is up to date with what's happening in this field, so has many valuable insights to share.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: the individual assignment presentations
Maybe could use a bit more background on CSR for those from non-business/management backgrounds (ie. FES students)

The assignments can be tough as an FESer without the SOM core. There's a steep learning curve and the lectures do not prepare you and are so different from the assignments. Also Todd should release a grading rubric for the assignments because his grading is really arbitrary and he will take off points for things he didn't clearly ask for. The assignment prompts should be clearer too.

Clearer expectations and LESS flexibility with the deliverables would have enhanced my learning in this class. I thought there was too much leeway, and as someone who unfortunately tends to do the bare minimum, would have benefitted from more lectures and fewer wishy-washy exercises or group work.

Overall, I learned a lot and found this class to be very valuable. The areas that I would suggest improving are the assignment descriptions and Professor Cort's handwriting, which was really hard to read! The assignments seemed unclear as to what exactly was expected and on the final assignment my group was graded down for neglecting to include something that was not part of the assignment. The assignments required a lot of research outside of the class and it would have been more effective if Professor Cort taught the subjects that were then assigned, such as information on the insurance industry, on the types of investing, or on topics related to the NS assignment.
I liked all of it, including the guest lecturers. Perhaps a bit later in the day for timing of the class would be my only suggestion.
the major improvement I would suggest would be to reorganize the due dates of the group projects so as to make it less heavy on the latter part of the semester.

I know Todd has reduced the amount of student group discussion, but I feel that these need to be reduced even further or restructured to make them more valuable. The conservation finance GreenLight session for example didn't help us learn much about conservation finance at all. Discussion what real conservation finance cases would have been more useful. Also it's good to always keep the group discussion short, not let it be the entire class otherwise students have the tendency to chitchat and not focus on the given topic. I understand that for every assignment there is no right answer and it's all about the rationale, but it would be great if Todd can give us more discussion time on the different "rationales" or approaches that companies/people have taken to solve the metrics/indicators challenge in corporate sustainability. More examples of approaches that have worked well or haven't would be useful.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: N/A

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: directly relevant to the csr field

Perfect! I focus on corporate sustainability so this course was a great fit and which also explains why I think it was the most constructive for me. The emphasis on rationale and stakeholdership in building metrics was an important takeaway and I think the instructor brought the message home clearly. I felt this course was distinctively practical compared to similar courses I took at F&ES. The business case emphasis was a key defining factor.

Environmental Policy lacks metrics in many regards. Development of environmental metrics will likely help the financing of many environmental-related projects and Climate Finance. This class was key for policy work which I hope to focus on.

I wanted to re-engage with this topic, in particular for the career I hope to pursue in working on building a more sustainable food system. It has been already extremely helpful in my summer internship!!
I am interested in corporate sustainability and this is a key class to take.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Natural Capital is an interesting topic and I will use the knowledge in my future job
interest in the subject.
Rationale, stakeholder interests, and communications are pillars to building good metrics and indicators. Understanding the landscape and evolving trends can also inform good practice.
To learn about corporate sustainability and metrics.
I work with data visualization and environmental metrics seemed like an interesting tie-in. I'm also trying to focus more on business and the environment.

I wanted to re-engage with corporate sustainability, a topic I had worked on for two years from within an environmental NGO, and get a more 'business' side approach to it, and integrate the two other dimensions of sustainability. I also really was interested in the metrics and indicator aspect of the course

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes, it did
yes
YES! The topics covered were broad yet relevant and expanded into areas that were less familiar to me such as data needs and accounting methods in sustainability.
I was disappointed and think the second half of the class needs to be improved.
For the most part. Would have gained more if I did more of the reading. I'm hoping to (re)visit the assigned texts over summer.
Yes, overall, I learned a lot from this class that I think will be relevant to a career in CSR.
Exceeded it. Great class.

yes absolutely! I did not go in with high expectations but feel the course gave me a good introduction to thinking about metrics, indicators, and all the different ways sustainability initiatives can be conducted.
Yes, definitely!

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: It almost emulates a real-world working situation

It's always a challenge to balance efficiency and depth in group work. Different views make discussion richer but don't always manifest into good deliverables. However, I think this was an important part of the course and should be maintained.
See above.
It was helpful that working in groups was permitted as the project topics were outside of my expertise so it was beneficial to have others to work with.
Very helpful for reinforcing class concepts.
I loved working in a group! The disadvantage is it can be time consuming.
There are 3 cases that require group work in this class so it is quite a lot to coordinate. On the other hand it is always nice to bounce ideas off classmates.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: pick a good group for the assignments

This is a very practical and constructive course! Very helpful to help navigate a field that is highly subjective and complex especially if you are interested in corporate sustainability. Readings are helpful. Don't come in expecting a right answer or formula rather use this course as an experimental lab to test your thinking against existing frameworks. Take this course!
Despite these areas for improvement, Todd is really great at reading these evaluations and working to improve his course, which I really appreciate and respect.
I recommend it
Do it!

Highly recommend taking it if you have any interest in corporate sustainability! Todd is a great lecturer, do *not* get put off by the negative comments of previous classes. He has made major improvements and really cares about his students and is very responsive. The course is pretty chill (little mandatory reading), and the projects are very interesting!!

Don't listen to those who say this course is about how to do GRI reporting. It's much broader than that and will help you understand important concepts in corporate sustainability management in general, not just reporting. We actually just mentioned GRI briefly and did not go in depth into it, as you can download the whole GRI set of reports and learn on your own. A must-take for those interested in business & the environment.
